text: - [Instructor] In this video,

you'll see how you can
automate IT operations

and IT Service Management or
ITSM with AWS Systems Manager.

Using Systems Manager
automation capabilities,

you can decrease time to
resolution of critical incidents,
reduce manual effort,

and improve your security
posture at scale.

Before we dive in, let's
see how you can gain agility
with control through automation.

You can automate operations
processes across environments.
Integrate resource configuration,
observability, and compliance data.

Use predefined or custom
automation runbooks.
Configure any of your operations processes
to trigger automations.

Integrate ITSM solutions,
such as ServiceNow

or Jira Service Management to
eliminate manual processes.
Perform automations at the resource level

or in the context of an
application or workload.
And surface compliance data in AWS Config
and AWS Audit Manager.

We're going to look at two
examples in this video.

The first example will
show how an AWS Config rule
can trigger an event in Systems Manager

that automatically
addresses compliance issues

through an operational work
item or ops item in OpsCenter.
For our purposes, an AWS Config rule

has already been configured to
detect specified applications

on Amazon Elastic Compute
Cloud or Amazon EC2 instances.
If a resource is marked as non-compliant,
an Amazon EventBridge rule
automatically creates an ops item for it.

Let's go to AWS Systems Manager
OpsCenter to take a look.
We can see an ops item was generated
for a Config Compliance task.
AWS Config detected that this EC2 instance
is running an unapproved application.

We can go into this ops
item to gather information
related to this operational issue.
We can also leverage automation runbooks
associated with this specific ops item.

For instance, we can stop or
terminate the EC2 instance.

Notice that hundreds of
other automation runbooks
are available as well.
For changes that need to go
through a change approval process,
we can leverage automation runbooks

to initiate Change
Manager change requests.
In this case,

we'll execute a runbook to
initiate a change request
to stop the EC2 instance.

We'll enter the instance
ID and specify the IAM role

reject or approve the request.

The reviewer can enter
comments about the approval,

the automation runbook

stopping the EC2 instance.

is still in a running state.

The Windows instance is
now in a stopped state.

This example shows how we
can automate IT operations

and automation runbooks

Now let's look at the second example
of automating IT operations with ITSM
and AWS Systems Manager.
This time, we'll look at Incident Manager.

Incident Manager facilitates
rapid incident response
to get applications working again.

In this example, Amazon
CloudWatch initiated an incident

for performance issues
detected on an application.
Let's open the incident.
We can see specific information
related to resources for this incident.
Let's take a look at the metrics.

High CPU utilization was
detected within our instance,
which triggered the incident
and notified all those involved.

we can also associate automation runbooks.
Let's take a look.

We can initiate runbooks
manually or programmatically
to automate IT operations and ITSM

within the resources
related to an incident.

We can see that a runbook
has been initiated
and is currently in progress.
Here we can see the runbook steps.
The runbook is currently initiating
the restart instance stage,

which will take a couple
of minutes to run.

The automation runbook has
successfully completed its steps.

In this example, it
restarted the EC2 instance.

To confirm this incident
has been remediated,
let's go back to the metrics.

As expected, the CPU
utilization has dropped,
indicating the issue has been fixed.
We can now resolve the incident.
The incident status is now resolved.

We now have the option to
create a post-analysis report
to help expedite remediation of
or eliminate future incidents.
